Dialogue.NPCText:
Before you stands a broad-shouldered, sun-darkened man swathed in a salt-flecked cloak and a wide-brimmed hat trimmed with golden thread. His smile is quick, but his eyes are always moving—counting coins, watching exits.

“Well met, friend. They call me Bakar of the Saltwind—merchant, gambler, sailor, and purveyor of all things exotic between Sunreach and Qasaria. If it glitters, I’ve shipped it; if it stings the tongue, I’ve tasted it.
What brings you to my corner of the bazaar—honest trade, hidden secrets, or something riskier?”

Option.text: I’m looking for work. Any trouble on your routes?
Tell me of Sunreach and Qasaria.
Are the rumors true—you run arms for Minax’s rebels?
Who do you trust in Qasaria’s Council of Jewels?
What’s with your outfit? Never seen those threads before.
Tell me about your past, Bakar.
Just browsing.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Bakar leans in, lowering his voice.

“Trade in these sands is never dull, and lately, it's downright deadly. My best cargo—spices and, well, more—was hijacked outside the city by those Ash Serpents raiders. Trouble is, they're not just after my coin. My crates are now arming desert bandits, and I’ll lose more than gold if the Sapphire Queen finds out.

Recover my stolen cargo, and you’ll find the Saltwind’s gratitude...and perhaps a secret worth more than gold. What do you say?”

Option.text: Point me to the raiders. I’ll get your cargo back.
What’s in these crates—spices or weapons?
If I do this, what do I get?
Who are the Ash Serpents?
I’ll pass for now.

Dialogue.NPCText:
He hands you a faded shipping manifest marked with the Saltwind sigil.

“Track their camp northeast of the old Sunreach caravan trail. Bring the crates back to me—intact, mind! And if you find a certain pearl-inlaid lockbox, keep it shut and between us, eh?”

(You have accepted Bakar’s Saltwind Delivery quest!)

Option.text: I’ll return with your cargo.
What’s the story with that lockbox?

Dialogue.NPCText:
He grins, flashing a gold tooth.

“Mostly spices, some rare Qasarian silks, a barrel of Sunreach saltfish... and perhaps a few steel blades for friends with sharper needs. War fattens the purse, but it’s not always wise to count your coins in public. Let’s just say, if you recover my goods, I can pay in coin or secrets.”

Option.text: Secrets? I’m listening.
I’ll just take gold, thanks.
I’m still not sure.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Bakar’s gaze flickers, measuring your ambition.

“The desert hides more than bones. Rumor says a shipwreck lies beneath the shifting sands—once a sea, now a grave. I may have a map pointing to a sunken shard of the Gem of Immortality itself. Help me, and perhaps you’ll earn a glimpse. But betray me... and you’ll wish you were lost at sea.”

Option.text: Now you have my attention. I’ll recover your crates.
If I find the shard, it’s mine.
This is too risky. I’m out.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Bakar laughs, loud and rough.

“If you find it, you’ll need more than luck and lungs to keep it. That’s a story for after the job, friend. Bring me my cargo first, then we’ll talk sunken legends and cutthroat splits.”

Option.text: Deal. The cargo comes first.
I’ll consider it.

Dialogue.NPCText: “You’ll have your choice—Qasarian coin, a cut of the best Sunreach saffron, or a rumor only a fool would ignore. Depends how much sand you’re willing to get in your boots. Now, will you take the job?”

Option.text: I’ll do it for the coin.
Tell me the rumor instead.
Let me think on it.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Bakar scowls.

“The Ash Serpents—nomads, thieves, fanatics. Some say Minax herself blessed their blades with shadow. They move camps nightly, but my last scout tracked them to a dry riverbed near the Qasarian border. Expect poison, curses, and trouble.”

Option.text: I’ll find them and get your cargo.
Sounds too dangerous.

Dialogue.NPCText:
He glances around, voice barely above a whisper.

“The lockbox? Let’s just say it was never meant for Qasaria’s council. Some say what’s inside is a map, or a curse, or both. If you open it without my say-so, don’t blame me for what follows. Bring it to me, sealed, and you’ll see your fortunes change.”

Option.text: I’ll handle it with care.
If it’s the Gem’s map, I want a share.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Bakar grins, spinning his pearl-hilted cutlass.

“Every piece tells a tale, friend. This Sunreach Saltcrown kept my head cool off Buccaneer’s Den. The Caravan Shirt? Stained by saffron and stormwater from half the world. My Spicebelt? Smuggled more opium than a Qasarian vizier’s dreams.
The Duster Cloak’s got more salt than the Sunreach docks. Sandrunner’s Driftsteps—try chasing down pirates barefoot! Even this cutlass—won in a game of ‘Sevens’ with a magelord who cheats with his mind.”

Option.text: You’ve sailed far, haven’t you?
What’s the richest cargo you ever lost?
Enough stories—got work?
Good day, merchant.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“Sunreach is a city of thieves and dreamers—if you’ve got a secret or a ship, you’ll make your fortune there. But Qasaria? That’s the jewel—gold domes, minarets, more secrets than sand.
The Council of Jewels run the city, but trust? That’s as scarce as rain. I trade with them all—Safiya al-Sapphire for coin, Rafiq al-Ruby for muscle, Yasmin al-Topaz for magic relics. Don’t cross Karim al-Emerald though. That one’s got eyes everywhere.”

Option.text: You deal with the council? Who do you trust?
Ever run into Minax’s agents?
Sounds like you live for danger.
Let’s talk business.

Dialogue.NPCText:
He leans in, eyes narrowing.

“Trust? That’s for gamblers, not traders. Safiya al-Sapphire would sell her own kin if the price was right. Rafiq’s an honorable fool, but he keeps the city’s roads clear. Yasmin? She’s more shadow than woman. Omar al-Onyx—if you hear your name in his arena, run. Karim? Don’t even ask.”

Option.text: Have you ever worked for Safiya?
Is Karim really in league with Minax?
Let’s get back to your cargo.
That’s all I needed.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Bakar shrugs.

“Safiya’s coin is clean but her business isn’t. Once smuggled a shipload of glass—turned out to be enchanted mirrors meant for Minax’s cultists. Never again. Take her coin, watch your back.”

Option.text: Who else pays for arms these days?
Back to business. About that job...

Dialogue.NPCText:
He eyes you carefully.

“Rumors are my second currency. Some say I run arms for the rebels. Some say I deal with Minax’s spies. Truth is, in Qasaria, everyone sells to someone. But I keep my loyalties for gold—and for those who help me when the tide turns.
You want to prove yourself? Help me get back what’s mine. Then, maybe, you’ll hear a real secret or two.”

Option.text: You have a deal—where’s your cargo?
I’m not interested in rumors.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Bakar grins and gestures to the bustling market.

“Plenty of trinkets to buy and tales to chase. If you change your mind—or need a spice to flavor your fortune—you know where to find me.”

Option.text: On second thought, got work for me?
Farewell, Saltwind.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Bakar's smile fades slightly, replaced with a distant gaze.

“Funny thing about the past. Most folk bury it in sand or rum. Me? I let it ride the wind.”
He taps his Saltwind cloak, the fabric stiff with brine and sun.

“You really want to know how a boy from the gutters of Sunreach ended up trading whispers with merchant-princes?”

Option.text: I do. Tell me how it started.
No thanks, I like my merchants mysterious.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“I was born in the alleys behind the Salt Quarter—a bastard child of a dockhand and a tavern dancer.”

He shrugs, unbothered.

“My first trade was a half-loaf of stolen bread... traded for a knife. My first lie? Told a pirate I was a prince. He laughed so hard, he gave me a silver coin. Been dealing in fiction and steel ever since.”
“Made my first big haul smuggling relics from Magincia after the plague. That’s when I met... her.”

Option.text: Who was she?
Did you ever return to Magincia?

Dialogue.NPCText:
He chuckles, a hint of warmth and pain.

“She was Yasmin’s apprentice, back when Topaz wasn’t yet draped in riddles. Her name was Layla. Smart, sharp, smelled like cinnamon and ink. She taught me that knowledge could buy more than blades ever could.”
“She vanished in the catacombs beneath Qasaria. Some say she sought a relic. Others… that Minax took her.”

“I still look for signs. Every tomb I open, every map I chase—I hope to find her trace.”

Option.text: That’s tragic. You truly cared for her.
Still chasing a lost flame? Sentimental.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Bakar nods slowly.

“The sea teaches many lessons. The first is that nothing stays. The second is that some things are worth remembering.”
“You speak like one who has lost someone too. That earns my respect.”

Option.text: I have. Thank you, Bakar.
Let’s move on. What are your hobbies?

Dialogue.NPCText:
He smirks.

“Sentiment gets you stabbed in a back alley or sold to slavers. But... she was different.”
“Anyway. There’s coin to chase. Want to know what keeps a salt trader entertained in a city of shadows?”

Option.text: I do. What are your vices?

Dialogue.NPCText:
Bakar leans back against a spice crate.

“I gamble. I chase shipwrecks. I collect carved dice from every land I visit. I once drank naga venom just to see if the hallucinations were prophetic.”
“Also have a thing for oceanic relics—pearls that whisper, coral knives, sunken charts. Lost one once to a Vesper noble who cheated with a rigged rune deck.”

“Still owe him a visit.”

Option.text: What’s your favorite relic?
Did the naga venom *was* prophetic?
Tell me more about those dice.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“An obsidian conch said to echo the voice of a drowned god. I traded half my fleet for it. Listened once. Never again.”

He shudders, eyes distant.
“But the conch is locked away. Someday, I might let you see it—if you survive what’s coming.”

Option.text: That sounds like a story for another time.

Dialogue.NPCText:
He laughs, clapping you on the back.

“Saw a city of sails flying over the ocean. A throne of coral. A face... maybe mine, maybe not. Could’ve been prophecy. Or just very bad rum.”
“Who knows? Maybe you're in that vision now, eh?”

Option.text: I’ll keep that in mind.
Sounds like you’ve seen too much sun.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“Got a set carved from serpent bone, and another from the teeth of a drowned kraken. Each pair tells a story—if you roll ‘em right.”

He produces a pouch, shaking it lightly. “Want to try your luck?”

Option.text: Roll the dice.
I’ll pass on games of chance.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Bakar rolls two bone dice across the crate...

The first shows a serpent.
The second shows a shattered crown.

“Interesting,” he murmurs. “You’ll face a ruler who’s broken—yet dangerous still. Might be a warning. Or a promise.”

Option.text: A warning, I’m sure.
I like promises better.
You believe that nonsense?
Let’s move on.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“Once. After the fires. There was gold in the ash, if you knew where to look. But the dead whispered in the wind there. No place for the living.”

“Still... I found a shard of something there. Could have been from the Gem. Could have been a broken bottle. But it glowed like truth.”

Option.text: Do you still have it?
You’ve lived quite a life.

Dialogue.NPCText:
He taps his cloak.

“I keep it sewn in the hem of my Saltcrown. A reminder. Some say Minax wants every piece of the Gem... but I’d rather keep mine out of reach.”
“Maybe I’ll show it to you—if you prove you're not one of her agents.”

Option.text: You can trust me.
I’d sell it to the highest bidder.
Another time, perhaps.

Dialogue.NPCText:
“Enough salt and story for one day, eh?”

Bakar pulls his cloak close and flashes a familiar smirk.
“Come find me again. I’ll pour you a tale worth twice its weight in saffron.”

Option.text: Until next time, Saltwind.
Let’s talk about work again.
